25. harsh folds which are not suitable
in places which stand out in strongest light,
As in the lap of his Moses,
but Titian, great, of fame–
his painting is in all ways full of life,
not only in nudes, but also
in splendid Fabrics with well-conceived folds,
as can also see in his woodcuts.

26. Reader, I would like to show you
many more Italians, well versed in their art:
Del Sarto, Tintoretto, Veronese,
the two Zuccari, and Baroccio.
These earn the crown for painting Fabrics
with grace and elegance. Yet succeeding well
with the beauty of Fabric lies always
in finely conceived folds.

27. But in offering you an Example from
Drapery of the Ancients, I do not wish
to waste words, for you should avoid them
in favor of these times. Indeed, they look like
nothing but wet linen, and hang like ropes.
In consequence, such Statues would require
very different drapery to be remarkable.
The poor quality has astonished many.
left-middleAmong the Ancients there is little or no good fabric.

28. I never saw Ancient Drapery in Rome
(if my limited memory does not deceive me)
that had any worth, except for some floating
on bronze Statues (unless I lack in judgment);
these resembled Goddesses,
whose Ancient Draperies might well
win the prize. I saw these
in the new Farnese Palace, above the gallery.
left-middleIn the Farnese Palace, some bronze figures of Women.

29. In the same Palace there is also a Flora;
her sculpted drapery is far from ugly.
But since I am discussing floating draperies:
If it is set indoors, the drape floats fully
behind the walking or running Figure;
but if it is outside, one must make a part
float in the direction of the wind,
that blows strongly or gently, from in front or behind.
left-middleThe Flora there as an example.

30. The mind must be employed in these works
to show a blast of wind pressing
these thin fabrics or pieces of silk against the body,
so that we can see, naturally, (if you succeed)
the knees, torso and legs of the nude.
